title: Are gold coins and silver coins. Considered "Jewelry" in chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: Is gold bullion, or silver bullion, gold coins and silver coins. Considered Jewelry under chapter 7 bankruptcy? Anyone, know? In other words, would the exemption applied to Jewelry of say 7,000 dollars, also apply to precious metals?
answers:
Orange County trustees would not consider gold bullion (coins or otherwise) as jewelry, but rather as collectables or other type of asset as their value is derived from the commodity itself not from the artistic expression of fashioning the metal into wearable pieces. I suppose if you were to somehow have a jeweler attach a chain to the coins and they could legitimately could be worn, the classification could be revisited.
Frankly however, whether the gold is considered jewelry, collectables, or a form of currency, it is likely that an experienced and creative bankruptcy attorney could help find a way to exempt these valuable items so that you could keep them as "exempt." The objective is to disclose the asset, and for the trustee not to sell them, exactly how we exempt them not tremendously important, as long as they're exempt.
Coins are considered as collectibles when the actual value exceeds the face value. Hope this perspective helps.

I believe that you can make a strong argument that the silver and gold are collectables or jewelry - whichever suits you best in regard to the exemptions. However ,in a vacuum, I would say that they are NOT jewelry

Typically jewelry is displayed on the body or clothing. The Trustee may object to a jewelry classification for that reason. You can definitely use your wildcard exemptions on the coins. Be sure to get a through consultation on this. You may not want to file Chapter 7 if you are going to lose assets to the Trustee.

That is a good question! Under Federal Exemptions, there is no specific category for precious metals that aren't jewelry. You could, however, use the wildcard exemption if you do not own a home, or if your home has no equity to exempt. CA may have an exemption that applies to precious metals. Depending on the entire scheme of exemptions and your specific assets, you may be able to use CA exemptions. I would recommend contacting an attorney in CA who will know the CA and federal law and be able to make some recommendations for you. Best of luck.

That is a great question. I have helped 8,000 person plus file and never seen that asked.!

Blacks law dictionary does not define.

If a states laws govern the exemptions then that states laws may define it. But if no legal description exists in the rules/laws then common dictionary meaning would govern. Such description is :

Articles of gold, silver, precious stones, etc., for personal adornment; and any ornaments for personal adornment, as necklaces or cuff links, including those of base metals, glass, plastic, or the like.

Thus if the coins were in the form of adornments..used somehow in wearing it, then it would appear to fall within that definition. Otherwise it would have to be exempted under another exemption. However, Gems, gold and silver are included in para 12 of the listing of assets in Schedule B of the bankruptcy documents you must sign. However, the exemption in Subsection 522(d)(4) exempts only jewelry, not gems gold or silver. Thus, another exemption must be used. Thus, a silver earing is different than silver for purposes of exemptions.

Filing bankruptcy involves many other issues and facts though which I will point out several for you now too:

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
